content.question: In each of three different collisions cases, two blocks of the same mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> can move on a horizontal surface with negligible friction, as shown in the figure. In each collision, one block is initially moving to the right along the surface and then collides with the second block, which is initially at rest. In case <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, the moving block comes to rest after the collision. In case <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, the two blocks move together after the collision. In case <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>, the stationary block is fixed in place on the surface and remains at rest after the collision, and the moving block changes direction but has the same speed before and after the collision. Which of the following correctly compares the changes in kinetic energy <math alttext="delta K sub A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>A</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta K sub B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>B</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="delta K sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></mstyle></math> of the two-block systems in cases <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math>, <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math>, and <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>, respectively?
